description: Dive into "Castles of Enchantment in Malaga" ‚Äî a handpicked list of places with quick notes, links, and essentials for fast trip planning and discovery.
title: Castles of Enchantment in Malaga

places.generalDescription: Colomares Castle, located in Benalmadena Pueblo, is a relatively new monument built between 1987 and 1994. Despite its recent construction, the castle exudes an old-world charm and features a unique blend of architectural styles including Mudejar, Gothic, Byzantine, and Romanesque. This makes it the largest monument in the world dedicated to Christopher Columbus. The castle offers breathtaking views as it stands amidst the treetops and white buildings of the skyline.

sources.snippet: Located in the Spanish resort town of Benalm√°dena, Castillo de Colomares is a monument dedicated to the life and times of Christopher Columbus. Constructed between 1987 and 1994, it was designed to resemble a fancy castle and covers an area of 5,000 square feet. While it may be the most significant monument of its kind in the world dedicated to the Italian navigator, it is in the Guinness Book of World Records for having the smallest church at just over six square feet.
sources.shortName: 19 Best Castles in Andalucia Worth Visiting

places.name: Colomares Castle

reviews.text: It's so beautiful, it has a hidden church inside. So many places for photo ops! It's breathtaking for it being considered small. The tickets were ‚Ç¨3 to enter so price is wonderful and we're thinking about having our wedding here!

Beautifully made castle with plenty of history to soak in. The guided tour is well worth it, offering interesting stories and details you wouldn't notice on your own. The grounds are lovely for a relaxed stroll, and there's a charming coffee shop on the premises for a post-tour break. A great place to spend an hour and step back in time.

Colomares Castle is an absolute hidden gem in Andalusia üåü. It's not a typical castle ‚Äì it's a breathtaking monument dedicated to the story of Christopher Columbus, blending Gothic, Romanesque, and Mudejar styles into one fairytale-like structure.

Walking through its arches, towers, and detailed stonework feels magical, like stepping into a fantasy world. Every corner is filled with artistic details and history ‚Äì from stained glass to intricate carvings. The atmosphere is peaceful and inspiring, making it perfect for photography, exploration, and learning. üì∏‚ú®

üí° Tips for visitors:
‚Ä¢	It's a smaller site, so you don't need hours to explore, but take your time to notice the details.
‚Ä¢	Go on a weekday for a quieter experience.
‚Ä¢	Buy tickets in advance ‚Äì it's affordable and worth every cent.
‚Ä¢	Don't forget to climb to the viewpoints for stunning views over the coast. üåä

A truly unique and unforgettable place that combines history, architecture, and beauty all in one. Highly recommended! ‚ù§Ô∏è

places.address: Finca la Carraca, Ctra. Costa del Sol, s/n, 29639 Benalm√°dena, M√°laga, Spain

places.generalDescription: Perched majestically on a hilltop, the Alcazaba is a stunning Moorish-style fortress that offers breathtaking views of the sea and lush gardens adorned with fountains. Constructed in the mid-8th century atop Roman ruins, this well-preserved citadel rivals even Granada's Alhambra in charm.

sources.snippet: There is also a military museum, which includes a small scale model of the entire castle complex and the lower residence, the Alcazaba. The best way to reach the castle on foot is via the attractive Paseo Don Juan de Temboury, to the south of the Alcazaba. From here a path winds pleasantly (and steeply) through lushly gardened terraces with viewpoints over the city.
sources.shortName: Castillo de Gibralfaro | M√°laga, Andaluc√≠a | Attractions

sources.snippet: It is composed of two lines of walls and 8 defensive towers linking the Alcazaba to the Castle. On the bottom, you can take a tour of the entire periphery of the fort. From its various viewpoints you can enjoy views of the city of M√°laga that can only be defined by the adjective ‚Äúbreathtaking.‚Äù During clear days, you can see the whole bay, the Strait of Gibraltar and even some mountains of the Sierra del Rif in Africa.
sources.shortName: Gibralfaro Castle: What to visit in M√°laga?

sources.snippet: The Alcazaba is one of the city‚Äôs historical and cultural gems and definitely one of the best things to do in Malaga. Located in the center of the city and at the base of Mount Gibralfaro (see below), this historic fortress-palace dates back to Muslim rule and gets its name for the Arabic word for ‚Äúcitadel.‚Äù Stroll through the Moorish archways of the fortress and take in the spectacular views of the city and ocean.
sources.shortName: 10 Best Things to Do in Malaga: Moorish Castles, Modern Art, & More
Ultimate Guide to the Gibralfaro (Castle) and Alcazaba in Malaga (2024)

sources.snippet: Sitting on a hill above a Roman amphitheater and below the Castle of Gibralfaro, the Alcazaba De M√°laga is a palatial fortification built in the early 11th century. According to experts, the Alcazaba of M√°laga was the prototype for several Moorish fortresses in the Taifa period. Its massive entry fortifications and double walls are similar to the Crusader Krak des Chevaliers castle in Syria.
sources.shortName: 19 Best Castles in Andalucia Worth Visiting

sources.snippet: Located at the foot of Mount Gibralfaro, is the Alcazaba, one of the most visited monuments in Spain and one of the most beautiful buildings in Andalusia. Built since the time of the Taifa kings during Muslim rule, it has become a must-see for all families and children, who can enjoy its gardens, stroll through its corridors and admire its beauty.
sources.shortName: What to do in Malaga with kids

sources.snippet: Situated behind the Alcazaba, the two buildings were connected by a fortified corridor and a walled walkway, which is currently cut off close to the fortress. For some time, the Alcazaba was considered the most impenetrable fortress on the entire Iberian Peninsula.
sources.shortName: The Gibralfaro Castle: a balcony overlooking M√°laga

sources.snippet: Even though the name suggests it‚Äôs a castle, in reality, it was a fortress built to house the troops protecting the Alcazaba under the foothill. So if you‚Äôre expecting beautifully decorated interiors and intricate courtyards, you will have to head elsewhere.
sources.shortName: Castillo de Gibralfaro, Malaga: Is it Worth a Visit?

sources.snippet: The ‚Äòcoracha‚Äô is a walled corridor that connected the Alcazaba with the Gibralfaro and allowed soldiers to move safely from one place to another. From the Alcazaba, they could access the city and harbour.
sources.shortName: Discover the Gibralfaro Castle

sources.snippet: The beautiful Alcazaba de Malaga, Bil-Bil Castle and the unique Colomares Castle are only a few of the many castles you can find in the province.
sources.shortName: 11 Beautiful Castles In Malaga (A Local's Pick)

places.name: Alcazaba

reviews.text:
The Alcazaba of M√°laga is a true gem of Andalusian history and architecture. Perched on a hill overlooking the city and the port, this Moorish fortress offers not only a fascinating glimpse into the Islamic past of Spain but also some of the best panoramic views in M√°laga.

The structure is remarkably well-preserved, with beautiful arches, lush gardens, and quiet courtyards that invite you to slow down and imagine what life was like centuries ago. The blend of military strength and delicate design is stunning - especially the intricate stonework and the refreshing water features scattered throughout the site.
PS:
A beautiful and peaceful place with great views over M√°laga. The architecture and gardens are stunning, and it's perfect for a short historical visit. Highly recommended!

Beautiful. Fabulous views, well preserved.
‚Ç¨6 adult entry.
Uphill, and some of it steep.
Need a good head for heights at times.
Cafe and a few sets of toilets inside.
Nice fountain courtyard to sit and chill.
Great vantage points to take photos and view Malaga or the port.
Not too busy.

Short queue to enter on a hot Sunday. Was ‚Ç¨7 each to go in. The ruins are immense, spread out over multiple layers and over a wide area. The views are incredible. There are so many features to see - gardens, walls, water features, galleries, etc. absolutely worth a visit. Seeing the uncovered Roman amphitheatre was a bonus too. Amazing place to visit.

places.address: C/ Alcazabilla, 2, Distrito Centro, 29012 M√°laga, Spain

places.generalDescription: Perched in the mountains above Malaga, Parador de M√°laga Gibralfaro offers a romantic and scenic dining experience. Located within Gibralfaro Castle, this cozy hotel features an informal restaurant serving simple yet delicious Spanish cuisine made with fresh local ingredients. The restaurant boasts panoramic views of the city and bay, creating a perfect backdrop for a romantic meal. Surrounded by pine trees, the hotel provides easy access to the city center and offers a rooftop pool for relaxation.

sources.snippet: What‚Äôs more, it is a beautiful spot surrounded by pine trees, which is in close proximity of the Parador de M√°laga Gibralfaro, from where you can make out the large boats and cruise ships docking at the port. Car access is not restricted, but there is not much space for parking, which is why we recommend using public transport, as it will take you directly to the entrance of the Parador.
sources.shortName: The Gibralfaro Castle: a balcony overlooking M√°laga

places.name: Parador de Malaga Gibralfaro

reviews.text:
I recently stayed at the Parador de M√°laga Gibralfaro, and it was truly an unforgettable experience.
The location is absolutely breathtaking - perched high above the city with panoramic views of M√°laga, the port, and the Mediterranean Sea. Waking up to that view every morning was a highlight of my trip.

The hotel itself is charming and full of character, perfectly blending classic style with modern comfort. My room was spacious, clean, and beautifully maintained, with a balcony that made the most of the incredible setting.

The staff were warm, professional, and attentive, making me feel genuinely welcome throughout my stay.
Dining at the hotel's restaurant was another memorable experience - the food was delicious, and enjoying dinner on the terrace overlooking the city was simply magical.

If you're looking for a peaceful, scenic retreat with easy access to the heart of M√°laga, I can't recommend Parador de M√°laga Gibralfaro enough. I can't wait to return!

We really enjoyed our stay. Beautiful location. Staff friendly and helpful. Room was very spacious and clean. Lovely rooftop pool area that could do with a little bit of a refurbishment. Maybe some plants and repairs to pool tiles. Also no drinks service up there. Maybe a cold drink vending machine? We only ate a few times for breakfast which was good but not the best value at 17 euros per head. Would stay again especially if the pool area was improved.

A Wonderful Stay with Breathtaking Views

We had an amazing stay! Parking was easy and convenient. The rooms were spacious, spotless, and peaceful-just what we needed. Having our own balcony with a stunning view over M√°laga was a real treat.

We enjoyed relaxing in the bar with delicious food and drinks, and took a lovely walk down to the old town and back. The route is ideal for anyone in reasonably good shape.

On our departure day, we didn't have time for breakfast, but the staff thoughtfully provided us with picnic bags filled with fruit, freshly made sandwiches, croissants, water, and juice. Such a generous gesture!

We wholeheartedly recommend this place and would love to return.

places.address: Castillo de Gibralfaro, s/n, Distrito Centro, 29016 M√°laga, Spain

places.generalDescription: Gibralfaro is a lush hill in Malaga, featuring walking paths leading up to a 14th-century castle with stunning rampart views and a museum. The Monte Gibralfaro Forest Park, located at the foot of the castle, offers an urban forest experience with dense Mediterranean vegetation covering nearly 300,000 square meters. The park boasts various trails for exploration amidst Aleppo pines, eucalyptus, cypresses, and other native flora.

sources.snippet: In the upper part of Gibralfaro Castle, in what was the former munitions dump, is the Gibralfaro Visitors‚Äô Centre. Here you can see an exhibition that traces the castle‚Äôs past as a military garrison, and as a coastal watchtower from 1487‚Äîthe year in which M√°laga joined the Crown of Castile‚Äîuntil 1925‚Äîwhen the castle was ceded, by royal decree of Alfonso XIII, to the people of M√°laga for their use and enjoyment. Admission to the castle costs ‚Ç¨3.50 and is free on Sundays after 2:00 PM.
sources.shortName: The Gibralfaro Castle: a balcony overlooking M√°laga

sources.snippet: It is one of the most emblematic places in Malaga, as well as one of the oldest monuments in the city. It was built in Roman times and later occupied by the Arabs during the period of Al-Andalus (VIII century), so your children can learn a little of the history of our Arab roots while doing some sport climbing the slopes. And as a reward they have the breathtaking views of the capital and the entire Mediterranean from the top.
sources.shortName: What to do in Malaga with kids
Ultimate Guide to the Gibralfaro (Castle) and Alcazaba in Malaga (2024)

sources.snippet: The upper courtyard houses a small building where you will find a castle museum showing different artifacts and replicas from the castle‚Äôs history. It was one long room filled with historic trivia which I didn‚Äôt find particularly interesting.
sources.shortName: Castillo de Gibralfaro, Malaga: Is it Worth a Visit?

places.name: Gibralfaro

reviews.text: The climb was steep but the view was worth it. The cost was 3.5 euros to walk around inside the walls of the castle. There is a small museum on the inside, free public restrooms, and a concession stand with refreshments.

As a castle it's a bit boring there, since most of it is destroyed and only some walls and a well remain, nothing else. But as a platform for a beautiful panorama it's quite suitable. At the same time, on the way to the castle, there is a pretty good free platform for a panoramic view (the last video).
The view is great as you can see the whole city from above. But the hike is a bit tiring and there's not much to see or do at the top aside from walking around and enjoy the view.

places.generalDescription: Castillo de El-Bil-Bil, also known as Bil Bil Castle, is a striking waterfront cultural center located in Benalmadena Costa. This early 20th-century landmark was built by an Englishman named William Leonard Hunt and features a unique architectural style that blends Moorish and Andalusian design elements. The castle hosts various events such as art exhibitions, concerts, and conferences.

sources.snippet: Built on the instructions of a French couple to look like a Moorish palace today, the Bil-Bil Castle is one of Benalm√°dena‚Äôs most visited attractions. Used as a private home following the war, Castillo de Bil Bil fell into disrepair and was going to be demolished before Benalm√°dena stepped in and decided to restore it and use it as a cultural center.
sources.shortName: 19 Best Castles in Andalucia Worth Visiting

places.name: Castillo de El-Bil-Bil

reviews.text: Beautiful architecture and decoration (tiles and plasterwork). Only small but worth a visit. Would make a perfect wedding venue.

Lovely little building and though modern it's been beautifully designed to showcase Andalusia's Moorish history - there's no other signs of it in the town so this is a nice touch. Just across the square there's a similarly designed archway/gate.

I think there's toilets and tourist information inside but it never seemed to open during our time there and there were no (obvious) signs for opening hours!

Recommend visiting at sunrise or sunset when the light on the surrounding promenade and beach is really beautiful.

Lovely building with information for visitors and toilet facilities.  Can't work out its opening hours though.  Set in a square at the beach so lovely views across the sea.  Tiles on the walls are lovely.  Has bands playing outside on special days like American Independence Day

places.address: Av. Antonio Machado, 78, 29631 Benalm√°dena, M√°laga, Spain

places.generalDescription: Perched majestically atop Mount Gibralfaro, the Castillo de Gibralfaro is a stunning remnant of Malaga's Moorish heritage. Originally constructed in the 8th century and later rebuilt in the 14th century, this fortress served as both a military stronghold and a lighthouse. While much of its interior has been altered over time, visitors can stroll along its protective ramparts to enjoy breathtaking panoramic views of the city below.

sources.snippet: One remnant of M√°laga‚Äôs Islamic past is the craggy ramparts of the Castillo de Gibralfaro, spectacularly located high on the hill overlooking the city. Built by 8th-century C√≥rdoban emir Abd ar-Rahman I, and later rebuilt in the 14th century when M√°laga was the main port for the emirate of Granada, the castle originally acted as a lighthouse and military barracks. Nothing much is original in the castle‚Äôs interior, but the protective walkway around the ramparts affords superb views over M√°laga.
sources.shortName: Castillo de Gibralfaro | M√°laga, Andaluc√≠a | Attractions

sources.snippet: I wanted to start off this list in the city of M√°laga itself, right in the heart of the historic centre. Castillo de Gibralfaro is often confused with the Alcazaba de M√°laga, because the two sit next to one another. The first time I visited M√°laga, I thought I had seen the castle, only to realize later that I had been looking at the fortress in front of it instead.
sources.shortName: 8 Castles in the Province of M√°laga Worth Visiting

sources.snippet: The only exceptions are Castillo de Gibralfaro and the Alcazaba. Most of them are in towns near Malaga and renting a car will give you the flexibility to explore them at your own pace. Check out affordable rental cars here .
sources.shortName: 11 Beautiful Castles In Malaga (A Local's Pick)

sources.snippet: If you visit M√°laga, don‚Äôt forget to visit this magnificent Castillo de Gibralfaro and the Alcazaba. Undoudtedly, two absolutely essential monuments .
sources.shortName: Gibralfaro Castle: What to visit in M√°laga?

sources.snippet: If you want to venture on foot, there is a pathway that leads uphill from Paseo de Don Juan Temboury which takes about 20 minutes.
sources.shortName: Castillo de Gibralfaro, Malaga: Is it Worth a Visit?

places.name: Castillo de Gibralfaro

reviews.text: Well worth the strenuous hike up (can get there by road, I believe). Very well maintained walls of the old castle. You can walk pretty much the entire length and the views are spectacular. Not a ton inside the castle walls, but the views alone make this a must do. Free on a Sunday after 2 pm. It'll be nice and quiet if you go before that and pay.

Great place to visit, but be prepared for a LOT of uphill walking. If you go in summer, bring super comfortable sneakers, a hairband, and plenty of water. The view from the top is absolutely breathtaking! They even provide fresh tap water at the hilltop for free, so don't forget to bring a bottle or flask. The total cost is ‚Ç¨17 to visit the main castle and the hilltop. You can drive up, but walking is more fun and a great workout. I did the walk in 34¬∞C in August-and I survived!

If you're looking to enjoy a breathtaking panoramic view of the city and the beautiful coastline, I highly recommend visiting this castle. The view from the top is truly impressive and well worth the trip.

You can hike up to the castle if you're in the mood for some exercise, the path is uphill and quite steep, so it's a good little workout. But if walking isn't ideal for you, there's also a bus available that will take you right up to the castle.

Whether you're into photography, sightseeing, or just enjoying a peaceful moment with a view, this spot is absolutely worth a visit.

places.address: Cam. Gibralfaro, 11, Distrito Centro, 29016 M√°laga, Spain
